    Getting Started

    You can utilize basic html and JavaScript or Webpack/Vite to utilize Vue. In this section we will focus on using npm, the Vue CLI, and webpack to spin up the Vue framework.

    What is Vue?

    Vue is a JavaScript framework used for creating user interfaces. It allows you to break down your application into much smaller components. This allows for more seperation of concerns and an intuitive way to structure an application.

    Downloading Vue

    To continue, you will need:

    • Node.js: https://nodejs.org/en/download/
    • npm: https://docs.npmjs.com/downloading-and-installing-node-js-and-npm

    Now with the terminal, we are going to get some native tooling. Install the Vue eco-system command-line interface, Vue CLI: 

              
    
  npm install -g @vue/cli

    Then pick a folder you want your project to be located in.

    In that folder, type this in the terminal: 

              
    
 vue create project-name

    After it is done downloading. You can now spin up your project: 

              
    
npm run serve

    Resources for Learning

    There are many resources to learn Vue from due to its large community!

    • Main Vue Documentation
    • Vue Mastery (Paid Courses)
    • The Net Ninja Youtube Video Course

    Common Front-End Features

    Why should you use Vue!? Vue is another Frontend Framework like React, Angular, and Svelte. All frameworks have their own unique system and way of doing things... Vue is no different. It has been described as "easy to pickup", but I think a better description would be "easier to collaborate with non-Vue and Vue developers alike".

    If you already know concepts like conditional rendering or using html with added functionality, then Vue is easy-to-understand.

    If you just know JavaScript, it's easy to get started. Because Vue looks like html/css/JavaScript! 

              
    
//Put HTML-based template syntax here
<template>
  <h1 class="mainTitle">Title</h1>
  <p @click="logToConsole()" >Click Me</p>
</template>

//Include your code and important functionality here
<script>
export default {
  name: "PageOrComponentName",
  methods: {
    logToConsole() {
      console.log("this is a console log!!!")
    }
  }
}
</script>

<style scoped>
/*Styles local to template on this file*/
.mainTitle {
  font-size: 5em;
}
</style>

    Quick Look at a Vue App's Structure

    The highlighted components represent three important parts of a Vue Application:

    • main.js
    • App.vue
    • Components

    File: main.js

    This file initiates the application with "createApp" from Vue.

    Also, if you downloaded a library or other package using NPM, Vite, or the Vue CLI, this is where you can add previously downloaded packages like routers, state management, and more to your application. In this example, we are wrapping store (Vuex), router (Vue Router), and highlightJS to our Vue Application then mounting it.

    Think about it like you are wrapping your application with functionality from another codebase. 

              
    
//Vue specific imports
import { createApp } from 'vue'
import App from './App.vue'
import router from './router'
import store from './store'

//External library import
import highlightJS from "highlight.js"

//Instantiate application and libraries
createApp(App).use(store).use(router).use(highlightJS).mount('#app')

    File: App.vue

    Here is the first parent in your application tree. From components, to complicated siloed structures, or even just a basic web page can be located here. 

              
    
//Using imported components "NavBar" and "ToDoListContainer"
<template>
  <NavBar />
  <TodoListContainer />
</template>


<script>
//Importing components
import NavBar from "./components/main/NavBar.vue";
import TodoListContainer from "./components/todo_list/TodoListContainer.vue";
import "./assets/global.css";

export default {
  name: 'App',
  //Instantiating imported components
  components: {
    NavBar,
    TodoListContainer
  }
}
</script>

//Basic styling scoped to this file's template
<style scoped>
html {
  height: 100%;
}

body {
  height: 100%;
  background-color: rgb(47, 93, 211);
}
</style>

    File: Components

    Just like how the App.vue file contains a template, script, and css section, components are formed exactly the same.

    These are Single-File-Components

    In the next section we go over each section of a component so you can understand how they work!
